intro: Antiphytum cruciatum, commonly known as the cross-leaved antiphytum, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae, which includes bellflowers and other similar species. The plant features opposite, lance-shaped leaves and produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue or purple. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or wetland habitats. Its unique floral structure and adaptability make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
